title: Israel’s Judicial Overhaul Plan Ignites Debate Among American Jews
description: Jewish American leaders are denouncing a proposal by the country’s right-wing government to weaken the power of the country’s judiciary, in ways that some call unusually forceful.

title: The Roots of the Georgia Protests
description: Always leery of Russian influence, Georgians see a new “foreign agents” law as a Kremlin-inspired tool to undermine their faltering democracy.

title: U.S. Intelligence Agencies Warn of China’s Efforts to Expand Its Power
description: China sees a partnership with Russia as a way to challenge, and potentially weaken, the United States, a new threat assessment said.

title: U.S. Military Repatriates Saudi Engineer Who From Guantánamo Bay
description: Ghassan al-Sharbi had been held by U.S. forces for more than two decades without trial. Prosecutors abandoned early efforts to charge him.

title: Ans Westra, 86, Dies; Her Photos Captured a Changing New Zealand
description: She created a comprehensive record of the country’s social history, her focus often falling outside New Zealand’s white conservative mainstream.

title: Your Thursday Briefing: Covid Origins Hearing Opens in the U.S.
description: Also, protests in Georgia and armed villagers in Kashmir.

title: Macron Calls for Enshrining the Right to Abortion in the French Constitution
description: President Emmanuel Macron honored Gisèle Halimi, a lawyer who worked for the legalization of abortion, but some of her family members and supporters assailed his use of her legacy.

title: Here’s What to Know About the Protests in Georgia
description: Demonstrators worry that Georgia is reneging on commitments to foster closer ties with Europe and moving toward closer ties with Russia.

title: Georgina Beyer, 65, Dies; Considered First Transgender Parliament Member
description: A New Zealand lawmaker, she fought for the rights of sex workers, L.G.B.T.Q. and Maori people, and won a battle to legalize civil unions for couples of any gender.

title: Pentagon Blocks Sharing Evidence of Possible Russian War Crimes With Hague Court
description: President Biden has not acted to resolve a dispute that pits the Defense Department against other agencies.

title: The Patriarchy Trap
description: Happy International Women’s Day to those who celebrate.

title: Wide Range of Pro-Ukrainian Groups Operate in War’s Shadow
description: The new intelligence suggesting the involvement of such a group in explosions that damaged the Nord Stream pipelines last year is extremely vague.

title: Greece Will Make Trains Safer, Transport Minister Vows
description: He also apologized for the crash that killed 57 people. But his words did little to sooth anger, as 40,000 protesters took to the streets in Athens.

title: Here is the background of the protests in Georgia.
Germany Cautious Over Reports That Pro-Ukrainian Group Sabotaged Nord Stream Pipeline
description: Defense Minister Boris Pistorius said Germany was waiting for further investigations, after reports in The New York Times and other news outlets.

title: Nepal Will Ban Solo Hiking in Its National Parks
description: The move, which the country’s tourism board said would improve safety, follows an earlier ban on climbing alone in Nepal’s mountains.

title: Adidas Looks to Transition as Losses From Yeezy Bite
description: After severing business ties with the rapper Ye, Adidas said it would cut its dividend but hasn’t yet decided what to do with $1.3 billion in Yeezy sneakers.

title: The Abortion Pill Fight
description: Since Roe v. Wade ended, the battle over legal abortion has largely shifted to access to pills.

title: U.N. Pushes for Grain Deal Extension
description: The secretary general of the U.N. will meet with Ukraine’s president on Wednesday to push for a renewal of the deal, which has helped ease pressure on food prices globally. Here is what we’re covering.

title: India Is Arming Villagers in Jammu and Kashmir
description: The government is reviving local militias in the Jammu part of the restive Kashmir region, laying bare the limits of its military approach there.

title: Georgian Opposition Urges More Protests Over ‘Kremlin-Inspired’ Law
description: Critics of proposed legislation targeting “foreign agents” say the law brings the country closer to Russia.

title: Yuriy Lutsenko, Who Played a Key Role in Trump’s First Impeachment, Loses His Military Command
description: Yuriy Lutsenko’s assignment as the commander of a platoon of drone operators near the embattled city of Bakhmut was short-lived.

title: E.U. defense ministers gather in Stockholm to weigh a new way of providing artillery shells for Ukraine.
Ukraine Needs Shells, and Arms Makers Want Money. Enter the E.U.
description: Ukraine is firing artillery shells faster than manufacturers can make them. Brussels is working on a plan to increase production by guaranteeing big advance purchases.

title: In Western Ukraine, Far From the Battlefield but Not the War
description: It has been more than a year since Russia invaded Ukraine, and life continues on. Babies are born. Children go to school. Some families go skiing. And a reporter is paying attention.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: High Russian casualties in Bakhmut.

title: Cuba Allows Some Major Leaguers on World Baseball Classic Team
description: For the first time, Cuba will allow some M.L.B. players to represent the team internationally. But many of the country’s biggest stars were left out, or declined their invitations.

title: Outraged Over Illnesses Among Schoolgirls, Iranians Return to Streets
description: With thousands of girls falling ill and claims of poisonings, Iranians held the first wide-scale protests in months.

title: Ukraine Claims Bakhmut Battle Is Wagner’s ‘Last Stand’
description: Ukrainians say Russia’s Wagner mercenary group is running low on fighters recruited from prisons, used in attacks on Bakhmut, where Ukraine has also endured heavy losses.
